Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: New Constraints on the Geodynamics of the Lake Bonneville Basin
Award.AbstractNarration:
The significance of this project is based, in part, on the rarity of this type of opportunity in geodynamic research. Lake Bonneville was one of the largest pluvial lakes on the planet during the late Pleistocene, has one of the best known lake-level histories, possesses multiple shorelines of known ages, and is now covered by the best topographic data set for any pluvial lake basin of comparable size. The convergence of these factors, as well as advances in modeling and analysis, will facilitate greater understanding of the processes and rates of isostatic rebound and accompanying crustal deformation. This study will provide a template for what is possible for geodynamic studies in lacustrine basins located in other regions and on other continents. In addition to developing new insights on the geodynamics of the Bonneville basin that will be used by geophysicists and others to better constrain viscosity models and understand the earthquake cycle, the results of this research have implications for other disciplines such as geochronology. Results from this work may also assist in geothermal energy exploration by better constraining the dimensions of high heat flow anomalies, which may be expressed by regions of super-elevated shorelines not consistent with their loading history. This project will also result in the interdisciplinary training of graduate students and be highlighted and disseminated to a broad audience through the Great Basin Paleoenvironmental Database website (www.dri.edu/gbped). In addition to adding to this database with new publications resulting from the research, the project will develop an online educational module highlighting the Bonneville basin's well documented environmental and geodynamic history. This module will be part of a larger effort to educate interested viewers on various aspects of the Quaternary history of the Great Basin.

The Lake Bonneville basin has become one of the premier examples of geodynamic research since the isostasy model of an elastic plate overlying a visco-elastic substrate was introduced in 1890. Since that time, the basin has been the subject of numerous studies elaborating on the timing, magnitude, and processes of isostatic rebound and the response of the crust and upper mantle to the enormous loads imposed by Lake Bonneville. The goal of this project is to employ much higher density shoreline elevation measurements, a more refined loading history, geographic information system spatial analysis of the rebound signal, and a fully three-dimensional finite-element model for simulating the isostatic response of the Earth. Since the last major publication on the rebound of the basin, significant improvements have been made to the lake-level chronology (loading history), modeling sophistication, three-dimensional analysis, topographic data, and the ability to define the geometry of rebound recorded by multiple, discrete shorelines. The combination of these improvements will lead to a much better constrained three-dimensional Earth model documenting lateral variations in lithospheric strength and viscosity structure. Geochronology results from the work may provide constraints on rates of shoreline development and also may lead to revision of calibrated production rates for cosmogenic surface exposure dating.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This grant project began 10/1/2015 and my part of the grant (based at Kansas State University) ended on 9/30/2019 after two no-cost extensions. I (C.G. Oviatt, emeritus professor, KSU) was one of three collaborators on the project to study the history of isostatic rebound of Earth’s crust in response to the addition and removal of the tremendous water load from Pleistocene Lake Bonneville in Utah, Nevada, and Idaho. Three integrated phases were involved in the research. The first phase was to survey and build on the existing data base of horizontal and vertical coordinates of points on the Bonneville and Provo shorelines (the two most-prominent shorelines of Lake Bonneville) using tools that would yield higher-precision results than had been previously obtained. Ken Adams (Desert Research Institute, one of the co-PIs of the grant) was largely responsible for this mapping phase using 5-m DEM data for the state of Utah, although Bruce Bills (Jet Propulsion Laboratory) and I (the other two co-PIs) participated in field-collection of some of the data in NV and ID where 5-m DEM data were not available. The three of us also discussed lacustrine geomorphology and data refinement. The other two phases of the project were to refine Bills’s geophysical model of crust and mantle behavior using the new data, and to improve the geochronology of Lake Bonneville (this was primarily my responsibility). All phases of the project are continuing even though NSF funding has ended. 

Lake Bonneville occupied the same hydrographically closed basin as modern Great Salt Lake (GSL). It grew to be almost as large as modern-day Lake Michigan, beginning about 30,000 years ago and reaching its highest level (the Bonneville shoreline), almost 350 m (1150 ft) higher than modern average GSL, by 18,000 years ago. From the Bonneville shoreline the lake dropped catastrophically about 130 m (~425 ft) during the huge Bonneville flood, when almost 5000 km3 rushed out of the basin in less than a year. After the flood, lake level stabilized because of continued river outflow and the Provo shoreline was formed ~220 m (~730 ft) above GSL, during a period of 1000 to 3000 years. After the lake stopped overflowing and became a closed-basin lake again because of climate drying, it regressed to levels similar to GSL by about 13,000 years ago. The weight of the deepening lake between ~30,000 and 18,000 yr ago caused Earth’s crust to subside, and when the lake regressed to the level of GSL at the end of the Bonneville cycle, the basin isostatically rebounded. The Bonneville shoreline is now bowed upward ~75 m, and the Provo shoreline ~60 m, higher in the middle of the basin than at the margins. 

The details of the age model are extremely important in refinements to the geophysical model. The history summarized in the previous paragraph is generally accepted by researchers in 2019, but note that ages in that summary are rounded off to the nearest 1000 years. Precision to the nearest 100 years would be preferable, as well as improvements in accuracy, and those were goals of this research. 

Studies of the geochronology of Lake Bonneville, partially funded by this grant, were conducted in various ways. One approach was to more-securely date the timing of deposition of a gravel spit at the shore of Lake Bonneville on the floor of the Sevier Desert. This spit formed when the lake had dropped ~65 m (210 ft) below the Provo shoreline during the regressive phase. Spit formation occurred sometime between 16,000 and 15,500 yr ago; this means that the end of the Provo overflowing stage had to be older than 15,000 yr (the rounded-off age previously reported). Another approach to the geochronology of Lake Bonneville was to determine the age of exposure of the erosional platform at the Provo shoreline based on cosmogenic nuclides in quartzite — that age is roughly 16,500 yr ago. 

Lake Bonneville has been studied for over 130 years, and tremendous knowledge has been gained in that time, but not without many scientific failures. All geochronology data collected during this project make significant contributions to the knowledge of lake history and therefore to the understanding of the isostatic response of the crust to the Lake Bonneville water load. One major contribution of the grant project, separated from the other information generated by NSF-funded research, is the age of the end of the Provo overflowing phase at about 16,500 years ago. This result needs to be further tested by future research, but it represents a major advancement in knowledge of the history of Lake Bonneville.
